fr.reflexe.viewshell.api.fs

Interface IFileEventContext

  • All Superinterfaces:
    IEventContext

    public interface IFileEventContext
extends IEventContext
    File system event context. For new and updated files, the most efficient way to access file content (if required immediately) is to call getTargetStream(). This recommendation does not apply when deferred processing is preferable.
    Since:
    1.0
    Author:
    REFLEXE Technologies

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      FileEventType getFileEventType()
      Gets the file event type.
      IPath getTarget()
      Gets the target affected by the event, as a logical path.
      File getTargetFile()
      Gets the target affected by the event, as a Java IO file.
      Path getTargetPath()
      Gets the target affected by the event, as a Java NIO path.
      long getTargetSize()
      Gets the size of the target file, in bytes.
      InputStream getTargetStream()
      Gets an input stream for reading file data.
      IFileWatcher getWatcher()
      Gets the watcher that triggered the event.
      boolean isComplete()
      Indicates, for created or updated files, if writing to the file appears to be complete.

    • Method Detail

      • getFileEventType

        FileEventType getFileEventType()
        Gets the file event type. This matches the invoked listener interface method.
        Returns:
        the file event type.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getWatcher

        IFileWatcher getWatcher()
        Gets the watcher that triggered the event.
        Returns:
        the watcher implementation.
        Since:
        1.0

      • isComplete

        boolean isComplete()
        Indicates, for created or updated files, if writing to the file appears to be complete.

        An incomplete event means that the file may not be ready, such as a file being written to over a slow connection or currently locked by another process. A complete event means that the file contains no data (such as a directory, or a deleted file) or that the file appears to have a stable size and a stable modification time.

        Returns:
        true if no changes have been detected to a file entry during a fraction of a second, or false if continuous changes have been detected for over 2 seconds (or the file is locked by another process). Also returns true for any delete operation or any operation involving a directory entry.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getTarget(), IPath.ready(long, long)

      • getTarget

        IPath getTarget()
        Gets the target affected by the event, as a logical path.
        Returns:
        the target file, as a path using the ViewShell API.
        Throws:
        FileSystemException - if the target cannot be resolved as a path.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getTargetPath

        Path getTargetPath()
        Gets the target affected by the event, as a Java NIO path.
        Returns:
        the target file.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getTargetFile

        File getTargetFile()
        Gets the target affected by the event, as a Java IO file.
        Returns:
        the target file.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getTargetSize

        long getTargetSize()
        Gets the size of the target file, in bytes. This is not useful for events for deleted files.
        Returns:
        the size, in bytes.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getTargetStream

        InputStream getTargetStream()
                     throws IOException
        Gets an input stream for reading file data. This is not useful for events for deleted files.
        Returns:
        an input stream.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the stream cannot be opened (if the file is locked or has been deleted, for example).
        Since:
        1.0
